body: Hussein Jaber, a Palestinian who moved from Jerusalem to Brooklyn 12 years ago, has creatively adapted himself to life in Sunset Park -- one of New York City's most ethnically diverse neighborhoods -- by hanging a sign in his bodega's window, which caters to the area's large Hispanic population, saying "Mexican grocery." body: Dr. and Mrs. Douglas P. Zipes of Carmel, Ind., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Lee Zipes, to Alan Eric Eskenazi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sy Eskenazi of Brooklyn. An October wedding is planned. Miss Zipes, 27 years old, graduated from Tufts University and received a master's degree in psychology from New York University. She is
title: Debra Lee Zipes Planning to Wed

body: Alfred Menziuso, an architect, and his Brooklyn neighbor Frank Guido, whose family owns the Guido Funeral Home, had long admired the handsome brownstone at 25 First Place not far from their homes in the Carroll Gardens section of the borough. Built as a private home in the 1890's, the house most recently served as a convent attached to the Roman
title: Postings: Carroll Gardens Units; Convent to Condos

body: EVEN an optimist would be hard-pressed to make the case that Columbia Street in South Brooklyn will recover the commercial vibrancy it enjoyed years ago. For Destiny has dealt it a series of blows. First came the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in the late 1940's, dividing Brooklyn at Hicks Street and isolating the Columbia Street district. Then came
title: Perspectives: Neighborhood Stores; Columbia Street Tips Hat to Commerce

body: THE elevated-train trestle outside the window might have been a hint. Nancy Hume remembers noticing the track, a scant 100 yards away, and even watching the train go by on the day she and her fiance, Peter Morse, decided to rent a sunny loft in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn. On the first night there, however, as the F train rattled past
title: First-Night Echoes: Torment of Moving

body: For thousands of New York City residents with no high school degree, passing the equivalency test is the key to getting a job, getting off welfare or pursuing vocational or college studies. But educators who prepare people throughout the city for the test say the route is increasingly obstructed by delays and bureaucratic complications that put
title: Roadblocks to Equivalency Exam Deny Many a Chance for Success
